project_management a); col_2 The enrichment planting conducted Infapro is achieved exclusively using indigenous species, aiming to rehabilitate the natural diversity of Sabah’s rainforests. The main species chosen for the project are indigenous dipterocarps of the Shorea, Dipterocarpus, Vatica, Hopea, Parashorea and Dryobalanops genus. These species were chosen due their extensive natural occurrence (hence ease of establishment), good timber properties and their ability to be vegetatively propagated. In addition to the dipterocarps, indigenous non-dipterocarps and forest fruit trees are planted. These not only act as suitable pioneer species for the more open and severely degraded areas but also provide food for bird and animal species, increasing biodiversity and restoring the natural composition of the forests structure. applicability_conditions_vcs_methodology_vm0005 In the baseline, the logged-over forest in the Project Area is unlikely to revert to normal regrowth patterns due to vines and climbers, which may include climbing bamboos, resulting from high-intensity logging operations in the past. In such cases, and subject to appropriate substantiation, regrowth of tree biomass before and following relogging in the baseline can be assumed to be zero. Where this is not the case, ex-ante estimates of regrowth must be made and monitoring of the baseline for ex-post confirmation of regrowth rates must be conducted;; project_activity Growth in untreated logged forest in the Project Area is suppressed by climbers and vine. Especially in the first years after logging the carbon sequestration that takes place in the remaining trees is neutralized by a high mortality due to damage caused by intensive logging. However forest regrowth does take place and therefore ex-ante estimations of regrowth are made and regrowth in the baseline is monitored, in line with the requirements of the methodology – see section 4.3.5 on Forest Regrowth.

name_of_verification_company: This report documents the validation and verification of the Infapro Improved Forest Management project against the Verified Carbon standard 2007.1 and its supporting documents, including the approved methodology VM0005 Version 1.0 Methodology for Improved Forest Management: Conversion of Low Productive to High Productive Forest. The validation activities included desk review of project design documentation and supporting documents, a field visit to the project area, interviews with relevant personnel, re-measurement of forest carbon plots, and review of calculations of the project’s net carbon benefits. The project seeks to rehabilitate approximately 25,000 ha of severely logged-over mixed dipterocarp rainforest in Sabah, Malaysia and prevent the relogging of the forest in this area. The review of Project documentation, the site visit, and subsequent follow-up interviews have provided SCS with sufficient evidence to determine the fulfilment of the stated criteria. The Project correctly applies the selected methodology element and is in conformance with all applicable requirements of the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS). The Project is designed to lead to reductions of GHG emissions that are real, measurable and give long-term benefits to the mitigation of climate change. In summary, it is the opinion of SCS that the Project, as described in the project description (PD) document version 1.7 dated August 19, 2011, meets all relevant Verified Carbon Standard 2007.1 requirements and correctly applies the selected methodology. SCS has verified that the project has generated 509,540 t CO2 equivalents of emissions reductions, after subtraction of leakage and buffer pool deductions.

The assessment of the likelihood and significance of potential natural disturbance events is subjective in nature. The audit team reviewed the project proponent’s rationale for each of these elements, which is documented in a risk assessment document that accompanies the PD, and determined that the risk assessments made were reasonable and conservative. Sabah Forestry Department Documents were provided that show that fire risk is low in the project area, and the audit team observed evidence that fire prevention measures are in place in the project area. The very high species richness in the project area limits the risk of pest and disease attacks. The site visit confirmed that the topography of the project area limits its susceptibility to flood damage. Landslides are a risk in the project area, but it appears very unlikely, based on an on-site visit of the area, that landslides would affect a significant percentage of the rehabilitated forest.
